commit_message:
Removes a redundant test from FernetAuthWithTrust

It turns out that the behaviour tests by
test_trust_get_token_fails_if_trustee_disabled is not actually different
between Fernet and UUID if the tokens are properly revoked. The original
test didn't ensure that any time had passed between creating and revoking
a token. This adds a new test showing the different behaviour and modifies
the existing test to works.

Previously this test would fail intermittently when hitting a second
boundary.

If the creation and revocation happen in the same second then Fernet will
indeed respond with a Forbidden. If the revocation happens at least one
second after it will response with the expected Unauthorized.

subject: Force a restart of all the apache nodes during upgrade
commit_message:
Force a restart of all the apache nodes during upgrade

During the upgrades, the venv path will change and therefore the
apache configuration file will change too.

However we apply the restart of apache after the keystone_service_setup
for nodes [1:] (the first node gets restarted as first task of the
keystone_service_setup).

So during an upgrade, because apache is up, the configuration file has
changed but apache still serves the old code (because not restarted yet
on the nodes 1 and above) when the keystone_service_setup is applied.

The keystone module can then hit any node in the load balancer, which
could be a different version.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring apache is restarted and
therefore runs the latest code.

Adding InfiniBand Support

InfiniBand is computer-networking communications standard
used in high-performance computing, features very high
throughput and very low latency. Where ethernet uses MAC
as unique identifier assigned to network interfaces,

that MAC is 6 bytes and GID is 8 bytes. Moreover to be
able to PXE boot on InfiniBand network we should use DHCP
over InfiniBand https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4390.
The major changes to allow it is to generate client-id per
GID and add it as DHCP option to the neutron port.

This patch update the neutron port with CLient-ID
DHCP option when ironic port.extra has client-id
paramater.

subject: Fix rabbitmq issues in run-upgrade.sh script
commit_message:
Fix rabbitmq issues in run-upgrade.sh script

This commit updates run-upgrade.sh to address the following two issues:

1. Ensure rabbitmq containers are restarted after their hostnames are
   changed, not before.

Currently, we restart rabbitmq containers before the updated hostname
is set in setup-hosts.yml, which results in the rabbitmq-install.yml
playbook failing to upgrade rabbitmq.  This commit moves the rabbitmq
container restarts to after setup.yml is run.

2. Ansible stores the ansible_hostname in its fact cache.
   ansible_hostname is used for the join cluster of rabbitmq.

If the ansible_hostname is changed during a playbook (like during the
upgrade process), the fact cache has to be cleared. That's what this
commit adds: after changing the hostname and restarting the container
with the new hostname, we can flush the fact cache and go ahead: the
next connection will populate the fact cache with the new
ansible_hostname.

NOTE(mattt): As we are running ansible_fact_cleanup.yml 2x, we have to
             create a symlink for each instance it's getting called so
             that the marker file is created with a unique name.  This
             ensures that re-running ansible_fact_cleanup.yml multiple
             times does not result in it getting skipped after the first
             invocation.

Change-Id: Ie97501a87f98ee88ddbfb2734db0642e7e80fae0
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk>

Analysis: While attaching volume to instance, Nova calls

subject: Revise container DNS resolution implementation
commit_message:
Revise container DNS resolution implementation

The current LXC cache preparation copies the DNS resolver config
from the host into the container.

When the host has been setup with a DNS caching system like 'unbound'
running on it, the host's resolv.conf contains only a localhost
nameserver entry which will not work from inside the container.

The Ubuntu containers use resolvconf by default. Resolvconf gathers
the DNS settings from each interface configured and compiles
/etc/resolv.conf from the interface information. This results in
a nameserver list which will start with the LXC dnsmasq service
which runs on lxcbr0. This service uses the host's DNS configuration
for name resolution.

In effect, therefore, when the containers use the DNS service on
lxcbr0, the host does the resolution and responds to the container.
This means far less moving parts and a far more predictable
implementation for name resolution.

This patch implements the changes necessary for this strategy to
work.

Change-Id: Ib139af5221dbb1f479ca068e472cf0e8aa828a8d

subject: Rework engine scheduler
commit_message:
Rework engine scheduler

This patch reworks engine scheduler to make it to work in "tickless"
way. The following changes were made:

 - Start_action method of scheduler is changed, it now always tries
   to acquire and schedule all actions in ready status;
 - Revise all existing calls for dispatcher.start_action in both
   service and cluster_action module: start_action rpc call is now
   being invoked without specifying action_id;
 - Notify scheduler only once after all node_create sub actions
   depdended by parent cluster_create action are ready since scheduler
   will try to schedule all of them automatically now.
 - Revise dispatcher.notify method to 1) broadcast start_action rpc
   call correctly, 2) use 'cast' rather than 'call' method to avoid
   blocking engine service for waiting for dispatcher's rpc response;
 - Use with_for_update to avoid race condition happens during action
   acquiring. Looks like current implementation of action_acquire db
   api can't avoid multiple engines locking the same action after
   they receive the start_action broadcast.

Change-Id: I5f6804b0ceb2341dcf2fa16c0f7d42972b7d6ae1
